posts.cooked: I wonder if any FIRST Robotics Competition teams have developed systems where robots observe other robots' positions to aid in navigation or strategy. As an academic exploration, I've been contemplating the application of advanced control policies—such as reinforcement learning (RL) and model predictive control (MPC)—for FRC. Specifically, for RL, simulating alliance and opponent movements appears beneficial for refining reward functions or adjusting system constraints. Regarding actual observation, utilizing a color camera equipped with bumper recognition could prove effective since these features are distinctive enough to differentiate between opposing or alliance robots. For RL training, exploring datasets from AScope recordings or developing models to analyze real video footage presents an intriguing yet potentially time-intensive approach. While this might not be practical for high school robotics competitions, it's always interesting to consider such ideas.

posts.name: kieran
posts.cooked: haven’t attempted this but it has also been annoyingly stuck in my head and won’t go away as something i want to do. I had thought about using depth cameras paired with color cameras to do something similar or running a depth model like the nvidia one that released a few months ago to try and detect moving robot shaped blobs

that's interesting—a stereo camera or even a lidar puck could definitely help though I feel like it might be cost-prohibitive… also a lidar would be difficult to position effectively on a robot, too high and it won’t catch anything—but too low, and it’ll be obstructed by the robot itself. Through the lab I intern at, I have access to the latest NVIDIA models and enough compute for training and processing… I'll see if I can run some tests soon. I meant Google VLA, not Veo 3.

posts.name: kieran
posts.cooked: The paper titled "FoundationStereo: Zero-Shot Stereo Matching" was nominated for CVPR 2025.

link_counts.title: GitHub - NVlabs/FoundationStereo: [CVPR 2025 Best Paper Nomination] FoundationStereo: Zero-Shot Stereo Matching

posts.cooked:
That’s my mistake, I wrote the wrong thing—I was using video earlier for some b-roll and it was stuck in my head—I meant the Google VLA models (paper). From what I’ve heard, NVIDIA should be releasing a new-generation VLA model of their own within the next few months. The paper you shared is quite interesting, but it might be challenging to apply it to FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) robots due to the limited sample size—especially considering how much things change annually. Perhaps integrating bumper detection with stereo vision to measure relative distances and combining it with localization for global positioning could help.  

I’m curious if QuestNav could also be implemented—the sensor suite seems like it might work for this purpose, though it would require further investigation.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: We tried reinforcement learning (RL) with occupancy grids and large language model (LLM) guidance. However, the results aren’t great—they can achieve basic scoring but fail to learn high-level strategies. We also tried model-based reinforcement learning, but the results weren’t great either. Another issue was the vision processing model, which used object detection and depth estimation—that wasn’t accurate and consistent enough for us. Currently, I’m working on a transformer-based end-to-end model. I plan to use mapping and localization for pretraining the observation layers, imitation learning for pretraining the action layers, and reinforcement learning and adversarial environments for fine-tuning.

That’s awesome, good to know… I just brainstormed a few ideas/suggestions, let me know if you’d like to expand on them later during your implementation.

I believe the core success of the RL system will likely hinge on a multimodal sensor fusion strategy, integrating pure vision (including object detection) with physical understanding of depth, whether through LiDAR, stereo cameras, or the Quest 3 Depth API. This approach may help reduce noise and potentially require self-supervised learning to align features effectively.

Adding dense intermediate goals or shaped rewards could assist in optimizing the reward function for the policy—I’m not entirely certain about this yet, have you tried it?

Additionally, considering the use of a spatio-temporal architecture seems crucial for capturing motion patterns and predicting dynamics.

Regarding action layers, synthetic data creation versus observing real interactions—log data appears preferable, though there’s uncertainty if occupancy grids would suffice.

Introducing an adversarial environment with a shared critic and ABM for alliance members might enhance high-level strategies, but it could also be overly ambitious.

I’d love to see examples of your prior implementations, including what you train on, the hardware used, and any other relevant details. This work is truly impressive!

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: Thanks, our goal is to let the model learn the strategies by itself rather than leveraging human guidance. I don’t have the latest results but here is a model trained using RL and occupancy grid with manual reward modeling for only a few hours.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: Currently, we are only training on synthetic data because it’s really hard to extract a large amount of useful information from match videos. We haven’t yet implemented it on a processor, but we plan to use either the Jetson Orin NX or the Mac Mini. The simulator we’re currently using is mosimulator, but we’re moving to Isaac sim for better realism.

posts.name: Sanjay Rajagopal
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

Just a few thoughts -  

I would definitely take a MARL approach if the goal is to find high-level strategies. Here are a couple of interesting papers that might be worth looking into for FRC use:  
- [2412.17993] Multi-Agent Path Finding in Continuous Spaces with Projected Diffusion Models  
- [1810.11187] TarMAC: Targeted Multi-Agent Communication  

I wonder if transformer architecture is the right approach to this training will be very inefficient and in the context of FRC I don’t see major benefits to using transformers over a simpler dot product attention mechanism for processing observations with algorithms like SAC.  

Would you need the RL to have a sensor with a physical understanding of depth to be successful? I think a CNN could handle the problem well enough.  

@Geoffrey8814 What RL algorithms have you tested so far? Which ones perform significantly better? What has your observation space been for your projects?  

Using RL in robotics has been on my mind for a while now and it’s great to see people trying it out.

link_counts.title: [2412.17993] Multi-Agent Path Finding in Continuous Spaces with Projected Diffusion Models

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: I don’t have the latest result, but I believe my friend, who’s working on the agent layer, mentioned that by adjusting the learning rate, he achieved good results using a simple LSTM. We opted for a transformer due to finding it challenging to train a straightforward model for high-level strategy. Our work draws inspiration from various end-to-end self-driving papers, the TEM-t paper, and several vision transformers. Additionally, we chose synthetic data because of the substantial amounts needed for training a transformer. By pre-training the transformer, it may accelerate high-level RL training since the model already grasps fundamental concepts about the game mechanics.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: A simple drive to a point with an object avoidance model requires careful planning. Zurich’s autonomous FPV and their robotic dog use a U-net for perception and an LSTM for the action layer.

posts.name: Sanjay Rajagopal
posts.cooked: What specifically is the high-level strategy you're evaluating for your models? Additionally, has the system incorporated selfobot data such as velocity, positional information via gyroscopes, and recent actions into the observations, or is it relying solely on visual inputs?

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: One example of the high-level strategy is the amplification in 2024. The model experienced difficulty with amplification, leading it to perform poorly in scoring accurately towards the speaker. Additionally, the model leverages both the grid and its speed and pose.
